prompt:
Create a LinkedIn post using the language and tone of Mikkel Jensen. 
The post summary is: Getting in the zone is important for doing quality work, but interruptions can be frequent at a busy workplace. Five tips are provided for getting and staying in the zone, including using noise-cancelling headphones, avoiding micro interruptions, and staying focused during a daily standup. The author believes that they can get more work done in three hours of focused work than in an entire workday filled with interruptions.
completion:
Getting in the zone is important for doing quality work.

But interruptions can be frequent at a busy workplace.

Here are five tips for getting and staying in the zone:


𝐑𝐞𝐦𝐨𝐯𝐞 𝐝𝐢𝐬𝐭𝐫𝐚𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬 𝐟𝐫𝐨𝐦 𝐜𝐨𝐧𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐬𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐧𝐨𝐢𝐬𝐞𝐬.
For me Airpods with noise cancellation do the trick.

𝐂𝐥𝐨𝐬𝐞 𝐬𝐨𝐜𝐢𝐚𝐥 𝐦𝐞𝐝𝐢𝐚. 
Micro interruptions are bad for focused work. It takes some time to get back to working efficiently on the task, even though it only takes 30 seconds to look at LinkedIn.

𝐁𝐥𝐨𝐜𝐤 𝐨𝐮𝐭 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐜𝐚𝐥𝐞𝐧𝐝𝐚𝐫 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐟𝐨𝐜𝐮𝐬𝐞𝐝 𝐰𝐨𝐫𝐤.
Especially those hours where You know You’re most efficient. For me it’s before lunch.

𝐃𝐞𝐜𝐥𝐢𝐧𝐞 𝐫𝐞𝐜𝐮𝐫𝐫𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐦𝐞𝐞𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠𝐬. 
As much as I like catching up with the team during a daily standup that only takes 15 minutes, it can destroy much more of Your productive time.

Imagine getting in at 8:30 and having a standup at 9:00. You’re reading a few mails, saying good morning to everyone and taking it easy before the standup, as nothing serious can get done in that short a time window. After the meeting everyone is getting coffee.

That one hour of the best time. Gone.

𝐏𝐮𝐭 𝐘𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐩𝐡𝐨𝐧𝐞 𝐚𝐰𝐚𝐲. 
Calls, messages, mails, notifications, all taking away Your focus.


I can get more work done in three hours of focused work than in an entire workday filled with interruptions. I bet this is true for most people.


How do You stay focused?

prompt:
Create a LinkedIn post using the language and tone of Mikkel Jensen. 

The post summary is:

🗄 Data is the new gold. 💡 Start with the data, building a solid foundation of structured data will help in business analysis and model development.
completion:
🗄 Data is the new gold ⭐


You’ve probably heard that phrase before. 

But what does it mean?


In the era of AI everyone can train, fine-tune and utilize a wide variety of models to their benefit.

Building a startup on publicly available data using open sources models might solve a valuable business case.

It will also be very easy to replicate.


Data is the thing that makes Your model unique. 

It’s the competitive advantage that nobody can replicate unless they gather their own data!


My advice:

Start with the data. 

Building a solid foundation of structured data will be helpful to almost everything that comes after, whether it’s business analysis or model development.


Doing the hard “unsexy” work is what set You apart.

prompt:
Create a LinkedIn post using the language and tone of Mikkel Jensen. 

The post summary is: 

Assessing the impact of ML & AI solutions involves considering whether the problem can be solved without AI, estimating the cost of development and implementation, and estimating the business value of the solution. It's important to leave room for errors and to consider the uncertainty of the project.
completion:
⚙ Assessing impact of ML & AI solutions 🤖 


Everyone is talking about ML & AI solutions and how they can benefit their business. But how do You know that developing and implementing AI is the way to go?


Let’s talk about impact assessment!

There are a few things I usually consider when thinking about implementation of AI (or any project really):


1 - Can the problem be solved without AI?

Always start with the simpler solution if possible.

Why? 

A simpler solution is faster to implement and more certain to work as intended.

A solution based on rules is fully transparent and understandable; You coded the rules Yourself!

Even if a more advanced model turns out to be the optimal solution, the simpler implementation has most likely provided valuable lessons about the data and problem.


2 - Estimate Cost

The cost of developing and implementing AI varies a lot depending on the problem and how ready the rest of the setup is. 

 - Need to collect the data first?
 - Is the setup mature enough to run AI solutions in production?
 - How is the output going to be used?

Creating a model for supervised learning on a structured dataset and exposing the results in an API can probably be done in a few weeks.

Developing a setup with data collection, storage, ETL pipelines, models and frontend will take much longer.

Estimating cost is even more important for early stage startups, as cost and opportunity cost are closely related. Spending time developing AI means not working on another - potentially more crucial - solution.


3 - Project Uncertainty

How certain are we that we’ll actually solve the problem in a satisfactory way? 

Some problems, like recommendation systems, have been implemented many times and are fairly likely to be solvable with the right data. 
Estimating development time and cost can be done with some degree of certainty.

Want to use a time series analysis for a non-standard use case on a dataset with tons of weird interaction effects?
Might take a few months just to investigate if that is even possible. 


4 - Estimate Business Value

Everything comes down to the business case.
This is no different from making any business decision whether it’s hiring, marketing, development or something else.

Leave some room for errors here. The solution should be estimated to bring home significantly more than its development cost.

-----------------------------------------------------------

In summary: If a solution is fairly straightforward and almost certain to bring more value than its implementation cost, go ahead and get it done!


What are Your considerations when scoping a new project?

prompt:
Create a LinkedIn post using the language and tone of Mikkel Jensen. 
The post summary is:
The author visited Alexander Bondegaard Pedersen and Kasper Bondegaard Pedersen at their office in Copenhagen to discuss implementing AI solutions into their influencer platform True Followrs. They discussed various AI use cases and how to estimate their business impact. The author provided context and new ideas, and recommended solving problems without AI if possible. They also offered to talk to other businesses and individuals about AI implementation.
completion:
Want to implement more automation and AI in Your business?
Here’s how We’ll get started!


Yesterday I visited Alexander Bondegaard Pedersen and Kasper Bondegaard Pedersen at their office in central Copenhagen, with the aim of providing context for implementing AI solutions into their influencer platform True Followrs.

We discussed several AI use cases and how to estimate their business impact, a vitally important task when you’re an early-stage startup. Building the wrong thing at this stage can be devastating.

They already have great traction and are exploring what to implement next.


What a great chance to connect and converse about optimization, automation and AI!
The main outcomes were:

 - Networking. We might need each other today, tomorrow, in a month or in a year.

 - Providing context. What does it take to implement the solution and how big of an impact will it have?

 - Get new ideas. More often than not we have a different view on things after conversing for an hour or two!


I’m taking the business’ viewpoint when talking partnerships & contracts, by using the following approaches:

 - Not recommending carrying out a project if I think it will cost more than the solution will benefit the company.

 - Being open about costs and whether I think a student, permanent employee or freelancer will be the best fit. I might even know the right person for the job if it isn’t me.

 - Recommending solving problems without AI if possible. It’s often faster, cheaper and carries less risks in terms of cost and transparency.

 - Look for existing solutions first. Perhaps the team even has the capabilities to create a solution themselves!


I want to talk to You as well! 🙋‍♂️ 
What’s the hold up?



And YES, suit + backpack is a totally viable outfit 🎒

prompt:

completion:

prompt:
Create a LinkedIn post using the language and tone of Mikkel Jensen. 
The post summary is: 
"The post summary is: Turning Coffee Into Connections! ☕ 

Met with Daniel Franch, a technical project manager, and Anders Holm Jorgensen, the CEO of proprty.ai, and had great conversations about freelancing and property management industry. Networking is a great way to learn new things, expand your network, and get new opportunities."
completion:
Turning Coffee Into Connections! ☕ 


This Friday I was fortunate enough to have a couple of meetings with two great people.

I met Daniel Franch, a technical project manager, who was available for a chat and interested in talking about freelancing.

We had a great conversation about the pros and cons of freelancing, how to find clients, how to stay motivated and how to handle the paperwork.

Freelancing is something I have been doing for a while now, and it’s great to have the opportunity to learn from others.


Later I visited Anders Holm Jorgensen the CEO of proprty.ai, a startup working on automatically estimating multiple aspects of a building’s health, which can help building managers and maintenance teams to plan their maintenance and reduce costs.

I love their vision and the impact they are trying to make in the property management industry.


Both of these meetings were a great reminder of the importance of networking.

It’s easy to get caught up in our daily work and forget to reach out to others.

But networking is a great way to learn new things, expand your network and get new opportunities.


I hope you all have a great start to the week!

prompt:
Create a LinkedIn post using the language and tone of Mikkel Jensen. 
The post summary is:

In this post, the author fine-tunes a pre-trained LLM to generate text similar to their own writing style. They describe the process of fine-tuning and provide code for others to use. The author notes that fine-tuning can improve the model's performance, but it still may not be as good as the original author's writing. The post also includes some observations on the limitations of fine-tuning, including hallucination and the need for more prompt engineering.
completion:
How I fine-tuned an LLM to write like me!



The latest trend in AI is Large Language Models (LLMs) and their ability to generate text, images and even code.

I wanted to try one out and see how it would perform.

I started by using the excellent and open-source tool Hugging Face’s Transformers For NLP, which allows you to browse, download and use pre-trained models.

I downloaded one of the most popular models - LLaMA - and used it to generate some text. It was pretty good, but not great. It lacked the nuance and personality that I try to bring to my posts.

So I decided to fine-tune it!

Fine-tuning an LLM is a simple process. You need to have a pre-trained model and some Python code.

Here’s the code I used:

https://lnkd.in/dJ5YHSpK


It’s still not as good as my writing, but it’s pretty close!

I’m sure that with more fine-tuning it will get even better.

What do you think? Have you tried anything similar?


--------------------------------------------------

Talk to me about AI, NLP, Machine Learning and Data Science!

👨‍💻 I’m Mikkel Jensen, a Data Scientist and AI consultant.


hashtag
#AI 
hashtag
#NLP 
hashtag
#MachineLearning 
hashtag
#DataScience 


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

This is part two in a series meant to showcase anecdotal evidence, for using an LLM's context window versus fine-tuning it. Link to the first post in comments 👇 

The text above was created using the fine-tune version of Llama-2, tuned on my old LinkedIn posts. I changed 2-3 minor things from the prompt output. Find the original output in the code!


Things I notice from fine-tuning:

Hallucination seems to be a big problem

Seems to resemble my style of writing much better than when using the context window


Next up: Fine-tuning with more prompt engineering.

Feel free to steal the code!

prompt:
Create a LinkedIn post using the language and tone of Mikkel Jensen. 

The post summary is:

The author is exploring the use of context windows in Large Language Models (LLMs) and how they can be used to steer the tone of AI-generated content. The author provides examples of how to craft prompts to achieve a specific tone and highlights the benefits of instant customization and brand consistency. The author also mentions the importance of fine-tuning the model for optimal results.
completion:
⚠ Context Window vs Fine-tuning⚠ 


I've recently been diving into context windows in LLMs and especially the topic of context window versus fine-tuning.

That is:
 - When is it sufficient to provide enough examples to an LLMs context window?
 - At what point are You better of fine-tuning the model?

In this series of posts we'll look at different examples to hopefully gather some anecdotal evidence for when to use what.

The first example is created with ChatGPT 4 with the prompt:

"Use the writing style in the following examples, to create a short and condensed LinkedIn post about how an LLMs context window can be used to steer the tone in the post:"

I have provided my last 10 LinkedIn posts as a reference.

Here is the outcome:

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

🚀 Steering Tone with LLM's Context Window: A Quick Guide 🚀

Diving into the world of Large Language Models (LLMs) can feel like unlocking a treasure chest of possibilities. 

But did you know you can steer the tone of your AI-generated content just by tweaking the context window? It's like having a dial to adjust the vibe of your content - from professional to playful, in no time!


Here's the Scoop:

Craft Your Prompts Wisely: Think of your prompt as the steering wheel. The way you phrase it and the style cues you include directly influence the AI's output. Looking for a conversational tone? Say it in your prompt.

Example Power: Throw in a couple of examples in the style you're aiming for. It gives the LLM a clear direction and ensures the output matches your expectations.


Why Bother?

Instant Customization: Tailor your content's tone on the fly, without extensive retraining or manual tweaking.

Brand Consistency: Keep your brand's voice coherent across all AI-generated content, ensuring a seamless user experience.

This approach isn't just efficient; it's a game-changer for anyone looking to leverage AI in their content strategy. 

Ready to give it a try? Let's chat about making your AI content work smarter, not harder💡


hashtag
#AI 
hashtag
#ContentStrategy 
hashtag
#MachineLearning 
hashtag
#LLM 
hashtag
#TechTips

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Things immediately noticeable:

Picked up that I often have a last line about chatting to people. I often want to emphasise that I like discussing problems and solutions with everyone who wants to!

I never use semicolon in my own writing.

This prompt is purposefully under engineered. Playing more with the prompt would help!


Next up: Fine-tuning

🤖 ML & AI use cases You can utilize right now 🤖 


Employ a Chatbot

Do you have a web page containing a vast amount of information?
Getting questions about how to find and use specific features?

Consider using a chatbot to act as a virtual assistant. Chatbots can answer a lot of the easier questions and offload customer support personnel.

Create a Recommendation System

The algorithms ensure that a movie or song that You are likely to also like is recommended.
Good for optimizing revenue per customer as related items are displayed in addition to what someone is looking to buy already.


Customer Profiling

Knowing Your ideal customer profile greatly improves the understanding of how to market a product correctly. 
How old are they? What do they do? Are they individuals or corporate?
Thorough analysis of the customer profile is a key part of targeted ads and ensures reaching out to the right people when selling.


Outlier Detection

Are You unsure whether an event is a statistical fluke or should be acted upon?
Understanding this can be crucial in decision making. 
Outlier detection is often used in finance to identify fraudulent transactions or monitor stock market anomalies.



Unsure of how to get going with any of the above?

prompt:
Create a LinkedIn post using the language and tone of Mikkel Jensen. 
The post summary is:

Developing ML & AI models requires a solid data foundation, quality data overview, data analysis and visualization, and basic automation. Start with these steps before leveraging Generative AI & LLMs.
completion:
Four things You should do before developing ML & AI models:

1: Create the data foundation

You’ve probably heard the phrase “data is the new gold” a bunch of times by now. And in case of developing ML & AI solutions that certainly is the case in many instances. 
Your data is what is unique to your business. Make sure it’s structured and continuously gathered.


2: Make a data quality overview

In Data Science there’s a saying: “Garbage in, Garbage out”. Your models are only as good as the data you provide for them. Make sure that this data is as good as possible before potentially building a model on faulty data.


3: Analyze and visualize your data

Basic statistical analysis and visualization highlights many important factors about Your data. This will probably answer most business questions and prevent wasting time on building a fancy solution for a simple problem.


4: Implement basic automation

A lot of tasks that are thought to be solvable with ML & AI can be boiled down to hard coded decision making algorithms. The advanced tools shine when there are loads of complex patterns and many features in the dataset.
If You have a few features and know how to make a rule based system from Your expert knowledge, chances are that this system will be as good as more advanced methods. 
It's a huge benefit having a fully transparent decision making tool, plus the development faster in most cases and thus less risky from a business perspective.


I’ve heard the same store so many times:

“We want to use Generative AI & LLMs to do X, although we’re not sure where to start”

Start with the four above and You’ll be in a great position to leverage Machine Learning and Artificial Intelligence.

What did I miss?

prompt:
Create a LinkedIn post using the language and tone of Mikkel Jensen. 
The post summary is: The author of the post has been playing World of Warcraft again and has noticed that the features that keep them playing, such as the compulsion loop and reward feedback, can be applied to work-related tasks. They argue that gamifying these tasks can be a powerful tool for staying motivated, as it provides smaller, more frequent rewards with a short duration from action to reward. The author wonders how they can apply this to their work-related tasks and stay motivated throughout the day.
completion:
I’ve recently started playing World of Warcraft (Again!)

And now you’re probably thinking: Why the hell would you post that on LinkedIn!?

Because the features that keep You playing can be applied to work related tasks as well!

The compulsion loop and the reward feedback in World of Warcraft is insane. I’ve been playing video games for my entire life, yet never experienced anything like this twenty year old game!

It’s funny how playing for hours on end seems so easily justifiable, when doing the same thing with work related tasks, even just writing a single LinkedIn post, can seem daunting and unpleasant.

This especially applies if you’re working from home and sitting alone, with no colleagues to cheer you up!

The feedback loop for many work related tasks is simply much longer. The time it takes from writing the many LinkedIn posts, creating that new Machine Learning model and serving it to the end user, or from planning a new feature to actually start working on it, is measured in weeks or months rather than hours. 

That is why gamifying work related tasks can be a powerful tool!
Smaller measure with a short duration from action to reward throughout the day.

How many useful comments did my post get?
Can I cold call X people today?
How fast am I able to prototype this PoC?

Several months without any subgoals to archive is just too long for me.

How do You stay motivated throughout your work?

Mads is open, friendly, and has a no-nonsense attitude, making him an excellent mentor. He encourages everyone to try coaching at least once in their career.
completion:
Be the positive impact you want to see in the world. Be like Mads Misiak Friis!



Have you ever considered working with a coach?

I first met Mads back in 2018 when I’d just finished my Master in Physics. I had signed up for a course focusing on how to build a startup, a course Mads was instructing.

He stood out as an incredibly open and friendly character radiating positive energy, while still having the no bullshit attitude you need when making rational decisions for your startup's trajectory.

So naturally, when I saw that Mads was arranging a weekend related to everything startup, health and goal setting, I had to join. The weekend turned into 3 months of coaching from which I’ve benefited immensely!


We’ve worked on several interesting topics:

 - Transitioning from a permanent position to freelancing; what to do when selling yourself in for a new project

 - Focusing on what makes you happy and removing stuff that does not

 - Eating healthier and increasing performance in work and private life

 - Balancing how to weigh financial outcomes with the mental capacity spent on projects and during negotiating



I think that everyone who has the opportunity should try it out at least once during their career.

Have a great day!

prompt:
Create a LinkedIn post using the language and tone of Mikkel Jensen. 
The post summary is:
Data scientists spend most of their time understanding the problem, fixing data issues, and building infrastructure, not tinkering with Neural Network architecture. While some may want to pursue a PhD in AI/ML for the rare jobs that require unique Neural Network architecture, the rest of us will have a broader set of tasks that involve designing the best solution, thinking about the best solution, and working with both database integration and advanced analytics. The job differs depending on the organization and role.
completion:
💡 The unsexy truth about being a data scientist 💡 

We’re all used to hearing about AI and LLMs at this point, some of the sexiest and most hyped tools in a data scientist's toolbox.

However, I regret to inform that data scientists spend most of their time understanding the problem, fixing the data foundation and building infrastructure around the models, not tinkering with Neural Network architecture.

If working on Neural Network architecture is what you want to do I recommend getting a PhD in AI/ML. You’d get to do what you love and actually have a shot at the few rare jobs where unique Neural Network architecture is at the essence of the problem.

The rest of us will have to be content with a broader set of tasks, which is great!
We get to:
 - Take a problem from idea to production, designing the best solution every step of the way
 - Think about the best solution, regardless of it being simple automation or the latest State of the art model
 - Work with both database integration and advanced analytics

The job differs, of course, depending on whether you’re positioned in a startup performing many different development tasks, or in a more specialized team in a larger organization.

What is your experience working in Data Science or with Data scientists?

prompt:
Create a LinkedIn post using the language and tone of Mikkel Jensen. 
The post summary is:
🌟 Three mistakes that can lead to overestimating model performance 🌟

1️⃣ Randomly splitting data without considering time series connections can result in overestimation.
2️⃣ Overfitting hyperparameters through extensive grid searches or automated optimization techniques without proper cross-validation.
3️⃣ Failing to monitor models post-deployment, leading to unnoticed performance drops and overconfidence in the model's abilities.
completion:
🌟 Three mistakes that makes you overestimate model performance 🌟 

1️⃣ Not realizing that data is in fact a time series:

Even though data points might seem independent of each other, they can have some non-trivial connection when collected over time.
Randomly splitting train, test, & validation data that emerges from a time series enables overestimation of model performance. 

A great example of this is Covid-19's impact on datasets. In a real-world scenario, a model would know nothing about how Covid impacts variables in a dataset. If it caused a data drift in any variable, there's a big chance that model performance will drop. 
This performance drop is not noticeable when splitting data randomly, due to all datasets containing data points from all points in time.

Fix this by using a sliding time window when estimating model performance, where T_train < T_test.

2️⃣ Overfitting Hyperparameters:

Hyperparameter tuning is an essential step in optimizing machine learning models. However, it's easy to fall into the trap of overfitting these hyperparameters. This mistake is often compounded by extensive grid searches or automated hyperparameter optimization techniques without proper cross-validation. This creates a model with great performance on the test set, that probably is NOT the best model for generalization. Wojtek Kuberski recently highlighted this in his excellent post.

Prevent this by using tools like k-fold cross-validation during hyperparameter tuning to ensure the model's robustness and generalizability.

3️⃣ Not monitoring models post-deployment:

Model performance often deteriorates over time. This is primarily due to changes in the underlying data distributions.
Without regular checks, significant performance drops can go unnoticed until it's too late, leading to overconfidence in the model's abilities based on its initial evaluation metrics.

Combat this by implementing a robust monitoring system that can detect performance changes or data drift and trigger retraining or model evaluation processes.

prompt:
Create a LinkedIn post using the language and tone of Mikkel Jensen. 

The post summary is: 🚀 A fast-growing startup in Copenhagen, Denmark, Daquma, is building a business around data migration and consulting, with a focus on doing the "unsexy" work and finding a niche. They have multiple open positions and offer the benefit of remote work. 💼
completion:
🚀 The fastest growing startup you’ve never heard of 🚀 


This Monday I visited Daquma's office in Copenhagen, a company in which one of my childhood friends, Sille Lie Barrett, is Partner and Senior Data Expert.

We spent some time with Peter Smedegaard Andersen talking about everything consulting and startup related, and about how they're building their business.

A lot has happened since I last visited 10 months ago, back when there were only 5 people employed. 

Their secret? Doing the hard and “unsexy” work in the world of data migration.

I think it’s a great reminder about building a business. A lot of people focus on the latest and greatest technologies and fail miserably. Finding your niche and doing what there is a demand for proves far more effective in many cases!

Check out https://daquma.com/ If you ever need some data experts or management consultants!



Perhaps you’re looking for new opportunities? Due to their hyper growth they have multiple open positions within the roles of Data, Management and Validation consultants.

A great thing about their setup is that you get to work on different projects as a consultant. But there's still the benefit of going to an office and collaborating with your colleagues as most of their projects are remote.
Best of both worlds 🙌

completion:
What's the greatest book on human relations? 

I’ve recently read the book “How to win friends and influence people” by Dale Carnegie, a classic in the fields of self education and human relations.

The book enlightens the reader about how to deal with people in many situations. Some of my main takeaways are:

Give honest and sincere appreciation:
Everyone wants to feel good about themselves. If you are the person that makes it happen, they’ll also feel good about you.

Talk in terms of the other person’s interests:
People are rarely convinced to collaborate solely because it’s beneficial to you. What’s in it for them?

Be a good listener:
It’s rare to have a conversation with an attentive and active listener. It makes people feel important and worth our time.


There is one point in particular which I can’t help to think is either outdated or not fit for business meetings. There are tons of anecdotes in the book where people went to a meeting and talked about personal interests of the counterpart, and ends up with much more than they came for.

This strategy probably works in some situations, however I know plenty of business people who value time and efficiency A LOT, who would be offended by me or anyone else wasting their time by talking about their desires and achievements. Sometimes we need to get to the point and solve the problems at hand.

What do you think about this piece of advice?

prompt:
Create a LinkedIn post using the language and tone of Mikkel Jensen. 
The post summary is:
🌟 Ever Wondered Why Success Stories on LinkedIn Seem So Effortless? 🌟

The post highlights the phenomenon of survivorship bias on LinkedIn, where success stories are celebrated, but the reality is that building a following takes time, effort, and consistency. The author, a data scientist, argues that it's important to value persistence and hard work, even if it doesn't lead to immediate success, and to share one's full journey, including the ups and downs, to provide a more realistic picture of success and failure.
completion:
🌟 Ever Wondered Why Success Stories on LinkedIn Seem So Effortless? 🌟

I've noticed a bunch of posts about how easy it is to gain a huge following on LinkedIn. Stories of skyrocketing followers and gaining exposure just by posting consistently are common.

While I agree that consistency is key to most successes in life, I also believe that there is more to it. It is possible for me to keep writing shitty posts that nobody wants to read for example 😅 


🔍 Let's Talk About Survivorship Bias.

Survivorship bias is like looking at the world through rose-colored glasses, seeing only success stories. It happens when we focus on people who've overcome odds and ignore those who didn't make it. It's like celebrating those who won a lottery but not thinking about the millions who didn't.

💡 On LinkedIn, this bias is common. 

Content creators with a huge following enlightens about how easy getting to that point is. Furthermore the posts, about the ease of getting a large following, gain a lot of exposure due to their authors following. But what about the countless others who are still struggling to get noticed?

👁️‍🗨️ Here's the Reality:

 - Not every journey is a straight path to success.
 - For every viral post, there are thousands that barely get noticed.
 - Building a following takes time, effort, and consistency.


📊 As a Data Scientist, I love digging into what's not immediately visible.
 
Survivorship bias is a classic example of how we can misinterpret the effort and skill some things require.

Let’s remember when browsing:
 - Celebrate success stories, but remember they're just part of the picture.
 - Value persistence and hard work, even if it doesn’t lead to immediate success.
 - Share your journey, the ups and downs. Real stories inspire!
 - Understanding the full story gives a more realistic picture of success and failure. 

💬 What are the stories from your life, where survivorship bias overshadowed reality?

hashtag
#SurvivorshipBias 
hashtag
#LinkedInRealities 
hashtag
#SuccessStories 
hashtag
#DataSciencePerspective 
hashtag
#RealTalkOnLinkedIn

completion:
Hey LinkedIn community! 👋 

Looking for a Data Scientist to add a fresh perspective to your projects this year? Let's collaborate in 2024! 🤝 I'm excited to explore potential collaborations with individuals, startups, recruiters and businesses and unleash the power of data! 


Why work with a contractor? Here are some reasons:

🙌🏼Flexibility: Scale your workforce as needed.
💰Cost-Efficiency and flexibility: Pay for specific project needs or make a deal about paying in part with equity!
💻Diverse Skills: Access fresh perspectives and innovations.
⚡Reduced Risk: Pivot quickly without long-term commitments.


Here are some areas where we could collaborate:

1️⃣ Predictive Analytics: Leverage historical data to make informed predictions, whether it's sales forecasting, demand planning, or trend analysis.

2️⃣ Machine Learning Solutions: Develop custom machine learning models tailored to your specific needs, whether it's for classification, regression, or clustering tasks.

3️⃣ Natural Language Processing (NLP): Unlock the potential of text data with sentiment analysis, chatbot development, or text summarization to extract valuable insights.

4️⃣ Data Visualization: Transform raw data into visually compelling insights. 

5️⃣ Custom Analytics Solutions: Tailored analytics solutions for your unique challenges.


💬 Let's Connect!

prompt:
Create a LinkedIn post using the language and tone of Mikkel Jensen. 
The post summary is: Learning about Natural Language Processing (NLP) and Large Language Models (LLMs) is essential for Data Scientists, as it can enhance their toolbox and position them as valuable assets in their industry. Free courses from Hugging Face provide a great starting point for understanding the basics of Transformer models and how to use and fine-tune pre-trained models. Additionally, the post highlights the various use cases of LLMs, including text classification, question answering, translation, text generation, and summarization.
completion:
If you’re a Data Scientist, it’s probably time to learn about Natural Language Processing (NLP) and Large Language Models (LLMs), as an increasing number of companies across industries are recruiting for these tasks. 
Learning about NLP and LLMs ensures you stay ahead of the curve, positioning yourself as a valuable asset, whether you’re looking for a new position or simply looking to expand your toolbox and enhance your current work.

The models can be utilized for so much more than developing the chatbots like ChatGPT, which really increased the popularity of LLMs. Here are a few examples:

Text classification (Sentiment analysis, Language detection, Urgency detection, etc.)
Question answering
Translation
Text generation
Fill blanks in text
Named entity recognition (NER), finding names, organization, places etc. in text
summarization

Why not start with a free course from Hugging Face, the place where most open source models are uploaded to and shared? https://lnkd.in/d3wy4jkj

This course will take you through the basics of Transformer models, the model architecture used for a lot of LLMs, along with how to use and fine-tune a pre-trained model or train one from scratch.
You will also learn about how a computer understands text data, and the data preprocessing that is needed for doing so.

Let me know about your favorite NLP & LLM resources in the comments!

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

💡 Let's Connect!

Share your insights, ask questions, and let's collectively shape the future of Data Science.

prompt:
Create a LinkedIn post using the language and tone of Mikkel Jensen. 
The post summary is:
"I never learned about personal finance and investing during education, but now it's an essential part of my monthly budget. I take some risk when investing, but the biggest risk is not getting started. I recommend buying stock in a company you like, thinking about the decision, and building a profitable portfolio. Alternatively, consider alternative investments like real estate, crypto, or startups. At least put some money into a mutual fund for someone else to handle."
completion:
I don’t get why I never heard a thing about personal finance and investing during my education 🎓

I remember learning about compound interest in math, but never how to use it to my advantage 📈

As a consequence I didn’t start investing until around five years ago, as I simply never thought about it as something I should do.

Now it’s an essential part of my monthly budget! 💰

Do you take some risk when investing? Yes
Did I initially lose some money? Yes

But the biggest risk of all is to never get started. That is the guaranteed way to be stuck in the rat race until retirement 🐀🏆

So go out there and get started if you haven’t already!

 - Buy stock in a company you like, it doesn't matter which 🏫
 - Think about why that was a good/bad decision 🧮
 - Reiterate and start building a profitable portfolio 🧾
 - Think about alternative investments like real estate, crypto, startups, etc.

At the very least put some money into a mutual fund and let somebody else handle it for you 🤵


And NO, your apartment/house is not an investment unless it brings in more rental income than its monthly cost, or if it is bought with the sole purpose of restoration and reselling for a profit.


This is not financial advice.

Have a great day!

completion:
Want to be more efficient in data exploration and developing baseline models? 📊

Start using OptBinning! 
https://lnkd.in/eAKnpFX5

I have been using it for quite some time and it works wonders 😲

With only a few lines of Python code it lets you discretize your variables, which helps with a bunch of initial insights like:

 - Investigate behavior in features; are there any special values/intervals?
 - Estimate predictive power of each feature
 - Look at interactions between features with 2D discretization

OptBinning also serves as an important part of preprocessing for a Logistic Regression model.

OptBinning is developed by Guillermo Navas Palencia, PhD who also just released RoPWR, a tool for piecewise regression 🤯
Be sure to check that out.

I hope you find these useful!

prompt:
Create a LinkedIn post using the language and tone of Mikkel Jensen. 
            The summary is: "The post summary is: Post deployment model monitoring is often neglected! 🤯 Monitoring features and models can have severe consequences. NannyML is an open source tool to make sure models have estimated performance and detect data drift. They recently added estimated model performance for regression models, which can benefit Risika's revenue estimation model."
completion:
Post deployment model monitoring is often neglected! 🤯

Machine learning is often used to be predictive and proactive in decision making, so why be reactive when it comes to nursing machine learning setups? 

Not monitoring features and models can have severe consequences. The damage will be done before noticing that anything is wrong.

I have been using an open source tool called NannyML for some time now, to make sure that models actually have the estimated performance and to stay on top of data drift.

They recently introduced estimated model performance for regression models, a much needed and very useful feature!

At Risika we have a regression model revenue estimation model that I’m sure will benefit from additional monitoring. 🕵️

If interested, check it out here: https://lnkd.in/edM5DydW

prompt:
Create a LinkedIn post using the language and tone of Mikkel Jensen. 
The post summary is:
Where are the next-generation algorithms for tabular data? Despite advancements in image, text, language, and time-series models, the state of the art for tabular data still relies on Gradient Boosting Machines. Emerging algorithms like TabDDPM show promise, but they have yet to surpass decision tree-based models. The search for innovation in tabular data analysis continues.
completion:
Where are the next-generation algorithms for tabular data?
 
Image, text, language and time-series models have all improved the past five years. Some examples are:
 
GPT - language model that generates human-like text
DallE - text-to-image model
BERT and variations - various text classification
TFT - interpretable time series forecasting
 
These are largely successful due to the development and adoption of transformers and diffusion models.
But what about tabular data? State of the art performance is still often achieved using a Gradient Boosting Machine. 
 
Algorithms like TabDDPM are emerging, but are still not (to my knowledge) outperforming decision tree based models.
 
So the question remains: 
Where are the next-generation algorithms for tabular data?


 
For the fun of it, here’s an example from https://lnkd.in/eYAFHb4w of an image generated from the text: Teddy bears working on new AI research underwater with 1990s technology


hashtag
#ai

prompt:

The post summary is:

We are participating in a hackathon to improve lead generation methods at Risika by combining three main ideas: identifying potential customers, filtering leads, and converting leads to online demos. Our sales department will test the leads and provide valuable insights on what works in terms of lead generation. Share your experiences on generating valuable leads in the comments!
completion:
Team LeadGenExplosion! 💥

We are four days into a hackathon which culminates with a “Shark Tank” style presentation tomorrow.

I have the honor of joining forces with these two gentlemen Frederik Franklin Eriksen and Karl Bindslev to have a shot at improving our lead generation methods at Risika.

One of our main challenges has been expanding beyond certain industries.

We are trying to solve that by combining three main ideas:

- Potential customers in other industries might have a similar company profile as our current customers

 - Company web pages can help us identify whether or not they are B2B or B2C. Our prospective customers are B2B

 - Our knowledge about the metrics we can use for filtering can be applied to other industries e.g. company size and financials

The leads will stand the ultimate test later today when our sales department will attempt to convert leads to online demos!

We will gain some valuable insights to what works in terms of lead generation, regardless of how successful we are.

What has been your eye opening experience in terms of generating valuable leads?

completion:
I’m turning 30 today!
 
Not that I’m writing a post to highlight my birthday, but rather as an opener for a stream of thoughts 🧠
 
I never made the Forbes 30 Under 30 list, the World's Youngest Billionaires or whatever all the hottest lists are called. And that is completely fine. Most people don’t 😱
 
What really does matter to me is that I can see changes and improvements on a personal and professional level when looking back a few years. Some of my highlights are:
 
- I have learned a lot by working with all the great and talented people at Risika for the past two years. I truly believe that this will turn out to be very beneficial for the rest of my career.

- I joined Longship Invest almost two and a half years ago and have gained knowledge about building your own company and being responsible for a lot of thing yourself, even in areas with very little expertise. This has also been mutually beneficial for my work both at Risika and Cyroinvest, as I have been able to use skills from the two companies to improve my knowledge and work in general.

- I recently started working on a new project with Ole Busborg Jensen, which I will be talking more about in the future.
 


Every once in a while take the time to think about what drives you and what makes you happy. 🤔

If there are some things that you want to do, start doing it.
And if you feel stuck and can’t see your way out don’t be afraid to ask for help.

Everyone has their own idea of what is important to them. Make sure to pursue those ideas.

I hope that you all have a fantastic day! 🥳

 
We’ll wrap things up with a photo from the Risika office

prompt:
Create a LinkedIn post using the language and tone of Mikkel Jensen. 
The post summary is: Landing a data science job after completing a master's degree can be challenging, but having a solid foundation in Python, SQL, and statistics can increase your chances. It's important to have a simple solution that gets the job done, rather than a complex one that may not be feasible for most businesses. The author also emphasizes the importance of developing the full model pipeline, rather than just a single component.
completion:
Landing your first data science job after finishing a masters degree can be hard. It took me around six months!

A lot of people get into data science nowadays for machine learning (and for good reason, it's an exciting field), and expect the first job to be something along the lines of tinkering with neural network architectures and optimizing parameters and hyperparameter for the specific use case. 
Let me tell you a secret: The jobs where those are the only tasks are few and far between! And while they certainly do exist the competition is pretty tough, as holders of PhDs and Postdocs in machine learning will be applying as well.

In most businesses the objective will be to maximize value in the most efficient way, regardless of how boring and unsexy the solution might be. I'm still trying to master this skill as I believe it's the most important one.

If you are just getting started with a career in data science:
- Have a solid foundation: Python, SQL, statistics
- Use the simplest solution possible to get the job done
- Learn how to develop the full solution: Developing a model is good, doing the entire model pipeline is great!

What are your most important lessons transitioning into a data science job?


------------------------------------------------------------------

Talking data science, credit risk, cryptocurrency, software development - Connect & start the conversation!

#machinelearning 
hashtag
#python 
hashtag
#datascience 
hashtag
#data

prompt:
Create a LinkedIn post using the language and tone of Mikkel Jensen. 
The post summary is: 

Great resources and libraries have come across recently, including NannyML for monitoring models post-deployment, 𝐎𝐩𝐭𝐁𝐢𝐧𝐧𝐢𝐧𝐠 for data binning, and 𝐓𝐚𝐛𝐃𝐃𝐏𝐌 for modelling tabular data. These tools have been found to outperform Smote and GANs in most cases.
completion:
Great resources and libraries I have come across recently:

NannyML: An open source tool for monitoring models post deployment. 
I find the ability to estimate performance without labels especially helpful, as we have a one year lag on our labels. It is also possible to detect data/classifier drift.

𝐎𝐩𝐭𝐁𝐢𝐧𝐧𝐢𝐧𝐠: The go to data binning library. Super useful for discovering interesting intervals in variables, and for binning and preprocessing before applying a logistic regression on top. 

𝐓𝐚𝐛𝐃𝐃𝐏𝐌: A new method for modelling tabular data. While I have only briefly browsed the paper, it seems promising for generating tabular data, outperforming both Smote and GANs in most of the tested cases!
The paper was published only a week ago, but I'm probably already late to the party talking about this one.

What are your favorite new tools?

Links in the comments👇

prompt:
Create a LinkedIn post using the language and tone of Mikkel Jensen. 
The post summary is: The author is sharing their personal experience with an algorithmic trading strategy in the Crypto market, specifically with Bitcoin. They mention that the strategy has doubled their initial investment, but they also acknowledge that the investment has still experienced a significant drawdown. The author highlights the goals of their company, Longship Invest, which include making it easy to get into Crypto, decreasing volatility, and beating the market over a period of 5 years. They also mention that they believe that solid statistics and fully automated trading software can help reduce errors introduced by humans and improve investment decisions.
completion:
As many have noticed, the Crypto market is bleeding these days. At the time of writing one Bitcoin is worth approximately 22.500$, a price level not seen since December 2020.
This is a special price for me personally, as it is the price where I “bought in” using the algorithm that I designed for Longship Invest, the algorithmic trading company that I am a partner in.
I am, of course, a customer in my own company. How can you expect others to use your product if you don’t believe in it yourself?

And how is the investment doing you might ask?
Currently I am sitting around 26% above my initial investment 💰

Is it the insane returns of 10x and 100x everyone has heard and fantasised about in Crypto? No.
Did I wish that the trading strategy had performed better in the latest downturn? Yes.

It should be noted that the investment had more than doubled at one point. The trading strategy is unfortunately not fully decoupled from market conditions and is still subject to the large volatility of Crypto, a challenge that we are aiming to improve on with new and better trading strategies 📈 

On the contrary Bitcoin is down around 67% from the top, which is far more than the 44% decrease I have been experiencing. And even though this is still a big drawdown, I believe that Crypto lovers are used to far worse conditions.

In Longship Invest we have three main goals with the product:
 - Make it easy to get into Crypto using a trading strategy ✅
 - Decrease volatility and increase Sharpe ratio of investments 🆙
 - Beat the market (Bitcoin) over a period of 5 years 💸

We will never be able to beat getting lucky and hitting a moonshot alt coin. But I think that we can come a long way with solid statistics and fully automated trading software, reducing errors introduced by humans and decisions made from bad judgment and from having paper hands. 


hashtag
#statistics 
hashtag
#investment 
hashtag
#cryptocurrency 
hashtag
#bitcoin 
hashtag
#trading
